title: Woman shoved cigarette papers up man’s nose then set them on fire
text:
Alyssa MacDonald says she carried out the assault after becoming angered at the man’s behaviour (Picture: Cascade news)

A woman has admitted pushing cigarette papers up the nose of a ‘vulnerable man’ and setting them on fire while he was asleep.

Alyssa MacDonald of Lossiemouth, Moray, Scotland, says she committed the assault after becoming ‘angered by the man’s behaviour’.

The incident took place on December 1 last year.

The man says that as he began waking up, he saw MacDonald standing over him laughing, as blood poured from his nose.

MacDonald appeared at Elgin Sheriff Court to be sentenced after she pleaded guilty to a charge of assault to injury.

The court was told that MacDonald and the victim were acquaintances, when the bizarre attack took place.

The man later went to Elgin police station with an appropriate adult to report the crime.

Defence solicitor Stephen Carty explained his client had committed the strange assault after becoming angered by the man’s behaviour – and confirmed the two no longer saw each other.

He said: ‘She didn’t intend any serious harm. It could be seen as a childish and immature thing to do but I have to accept that this goes beyond that – Miss MacDonald is an adult and she certainly knows better.

‘I can’t hide the fact that she got herself into similar situations last year and she is putting herself in the precarious situation where the court could impose a custodial sentence.’

Sheriff Olga Pasportnikov, deferred sentence for six months to April 16 next year, to allow MacDonald to engage with ‘appropriate services’.

description: The man woke up to the smell of burning and realised his nose was on fire.
